diciamo che la VPN ti assegna un IP di un altro paese per cui puoi essere agganciato a internet dal tuo ISP a Bali ma quando ti colleghi a un website vieni riconosciuto come collegato da un altro paese (per esempio l'italia). In questo modo puoi bypassare i filtri IP dei paesi esteri che non ti fanno vedere la RAI per esempio. Ora l'ultimo tratto tra il tuo PC e il sever VPN a cui ti colleghi (per esempio il server Italiano) dovrebbe essere criptato per bene e qui dipende da che fornitore di VPN scegli. Poi ci sono comunque casi in cui gli ISP e anche i provider di VPN possono essere costretti ad aprire la criptografazione e rivelare il tuo traffico nel caso di data forensic investigation in casi molto gravi di cybersecurity breach oppure attacci terroristici.

[NAME] Union and [NAME] a Duty-[NAME] Agreement for [NAME] Goods
Tuesday, September 23, 2025 11:58 IWST
[NAME] Union and Indonesia signed a trade deal that cuts tariffs to zero on 96% of goods within five years, including cars, machinery and food products.
This agreement is expected to increase [NAME] exports to Indonesia by around 30% or three billion euros.
Indonesia's nickel export ban remains in place despite both sides promising to strengthen trade cooperation.

Ipotnews - [NAME] Union and Indonesia have secured a trade deal that will eliminate tariffs or reduce them to near zero on almost all goods. This agreement strengthens the relationship between the two partners amid US [NAME] Trump's moves that have shaken global trade.
The deal will also remove restrictions on transactions in key raw materials, said EU [NAME] [NAME]. He added that European exporters will save around 600 million euros in tariffs thanks to the agreement.
"We are really opening a huge new chapter," said Sefcovic, who arrived in Indonesia on Monday, following the conclusion of negotiations after almost a decade. "Our trade with Indonesia is actually far below its potential," he added, as quoted by Bloomberg, Tuesday (September 23). He referred to Indonesia's economy, which is larger than Vietnam, the Philippines, and Thailand combined.
For the EU, the agreement with Jakarta will play a crucial role in diversifying its supply chain, especially for raw materials. The deal also opens up new markets amid the 15% tariff imposed by the US on most EU exports.
European officials have stepped up negotiations with several major world economies, including India, and finalized talks with the [NAME] Mercosur bloc, which includes Brazil and Argentina. The EU is also accelerating talks with Vietnam, the Philippines, and Thailand.
The agreement will reduce tariffs to zero on 96% of goods within five years. This is expected to increase EU exports to Indonesia by at least 30%, or around three billion euros. EU car tariffs will fall from 50% to zero within five years, while duties on machinery and equipment will be cut from 30% to zero immediately. Agricultural and food products will also benefit from trade liberalization.
For chemicals and other materials exported from the EU, the agreement will eliminate licensing and other restrictions. Meanwhile, the EU will receive preferential tariff treatment for exports of Indonesian raw materials after an initial processing stage. However, the agreement will not change the ban on Indonesian businesses exporting nickel to the EU, which is the subject of a dispute at the [NAME] Organization (WTO). Indonesia is
a key partner for the EU, but bilateral relations have been strained by EU deforestation regulations targeting land clearing for palm oil and coffee plantations. Indonesia has been among the most vocal critics of the rule.
The agreement will not affect the implementation of the regulation in Indonesia, an issue also discussed in the negotiations. However, Sefcovic said the agreement will create a platform to help Indonesian companies, especially small exporters, meet their EU obligations.
The agreement still requires approval from EU member states and the [NAME], as well as Indonesia's legislature, before it comes into force.
Sefcovic called the agreement a "very clear framework" that will boost trade and create opportunities for both parties.  (Bloomberg)

The deal will also remove restrictions on transactions in key raw materials, said EU [NAME] [NAME]. He added that European exporters will save around 600 million euros in tariffs thanks to the agreement.
"We are really opening a huge new chapter," said Sefcovic, who arrived in Indonesia on Monday, following the conclusion of negotiations after almost a decade. "Our trade with Indonesia is actually far below its potential," he added, as quoted by Bloomberg, Tuesday (September 23). He referred to Indonesia's economy, which is larger than Vietnam, the Philippines, and Thailand combined.
For the EU, the agreement with Jakarta will play a crucial role in diversifying its supply chain, especially for raw materials. The deal also opens up new markets amid the 15% tariff imposed by the US on most EU exports.
European officials have stepped up negotiations with several major world economies, including India, and finalized talks with the [NAME] Mercosur bloc, which includes Brazil and Argentina. The EU is also accelerating talks with Vietnam, the Philippines, and Thailand.
The agreement will reduce tariffs to zero on 96% of goods within five years. This is expected to increase EU exports to Indonesia by at least 30%, or around three billion euros. EU car tariffs will fall from 50% to zero within five years, while duties on machinery and equipment will be cut from 30% to zero immediately. Agricultural and food products will also benefit from trade liberalization.
For chemicals and other materials exported from the EU, the agreement will eliminate licensing and other restrictions. Meanwhile, the EU will receive preferential tariff treatment for exports of Indonesian raw materials after an initial processing stage. However, the agreement will not change the ban on Indonesian businesses exporting nickel to the EU, which is the subject of a dispute at the [NAME] Organization (WTO). Indonesia is
a key partner for the EU, but bilateral relations have been strained by EU deforestation regulations targeting land clearing for palm oil and coffee plantations. Indonesia has been among the most vocal critics of the rule.
The agreement will not affect the implementation of the regulation in Indonesia, an issue also discussed in the negotiations. However, Sefcovic said the agreement will create a platform to help Indonesian companies, especially small exporters, meet their EU obligations.
The agreement still requires approval from EU member states and the [NAME], as well as Indonesia's legislature, before it comes into force.
Sefcovic called the agreement a "very clear framework" that will boost trade and create opportunities for both parties.  (Bloomberg)
